reviewText: After a long line of disappointing games in the Medal of Honor franchise that just never could recapture the magic successes of Allied Assault, we finally get Medal of Honor: Airborne that combines high presentation values and good, fast-paced fun. While there's definitely some good entertainment value here, the campaign is short, and the multiplayer isn't incredibly deep. Still, it's a good game overall and the best game in the franchise in some time.\n\nMedal of Honor: Airborne takes a different approach to World War II shooters. Instead of starting players out in each linear level on a path where there's no variation, EA LA decided to let us choose where to start each mission by throwing us out of a plane. Once floating in the air, it's a matter of steering the parachute to the best location to start the fight. Where the best location is depends on how you want to play the game, a mechanic that certainly is useful if you want a challenge or find that it's more fun to start out in a certain place on a map. It also provides an opportunity to drop into a new location if the previous one was a little too difficult or even complete one of the five different skill drops (drops in very specific areas).

reviewText: Since Call of Duty 4 was released in 2007, the Modern Military Shooter has become one of the most successful genres in videogame history.  This generation has seen its rise, and I do believe that before the end, it will also witness the genre's fall.  Already, we're seeing outcry against the restrictive linearity and setpiece-heavy design that are MMSs bread and butter.  We saw something similar happen with WWII shooters.  They gained popularity near the beginning of last generation, and eventually fell out of favor near the beginning of the current generation.  Medal of Honor: Airborne was one of the last ones to be released, and it struggled to win over audiences who were weary of its familiar setting and scenarios.  The fact that Call of Duty 4 came out a few months later certainly didn't help.  So basically, it didn't take people long to forget about the game.  However, this isn't 2007.  We've had some time to stew in the MMS scene, and WWII is starting to look less horribly overwrought and more whimsically nostalgic.  And if you look past its well-worn setting, Airborne is quite a fun shooter that manages to set itself apart from the pack with a variety of interesting features.\n\nRead more[videogamepotpourri.blogspot.com]

reviewText: This game is worth playing through at least twice even now in 2015, as most of us are aware now graphics and compatibility issues can make current games a nightmare. The ability to land wherever you want on the map is a large part of the fun but it also is a decent game in general. Getting headshots with rifles and other guns feels rewarding as well as mowing through Nazis with assault weapons. The MG42 adds some realism and you'll know when the enemy has it as well as learn to fear it if you don't take it out immediately. I'd recommend playing this game on the medium difficulty setting first so you can unlock all the weapon upgrades and learn the safe areas of the game as well as get used to the cover system first. It's a fun game and most of the time when you die you get to parachute in again but there are some glitchy enemies that you'll see firing at your teammates then a quarter of a second later will instantly turn to face you, it's not too often but it can be frustrating on your first playthough. On one level the enemy snipers may fire through walls so be careful as you move up and your teammates don't help too much in that same tank factory level but as long as you use the right weapons in the right situations you'll usually be fine. The best guns are: shotgun, STG44 (you can take the scope off when you unlock it), Gewehr, Garand (and unzoom this gun), and the Springfield but the upgraded Thompson, Bar, and K98K, etc. are enjoyable to use as well. The whole premise of the game is you can land wherever you want and I've avoided whole trench lines and seen some potential landing spots right at the objectives where as other times its fun to land on rooftops with the Springfield Sniper. The campaign is short but play thorugh it more then once and try different tactics, it will be worth your time. If you have a new copy of PHYS X it may not work with game so download it from here, it's the legacy version, no uninstall needed. reviewText:
This is a very nice game about the American 82nd and 101st Airborne divisions of WWII. The spawning system involves jumping about of a plane and parachuting down on your enemies, which is rather exciting. Another thing worthy of note is that during the campaign, you face Tiger I tanks. You know, the killing machines that were feared by Sherman tanks everywhere. These monsters are not at all unwilling to lob their 88mm HE rounds directly at your face, which, quite fittingly, is an insta-kill. The only way to retaliate against them is with Gammon grenades or an AT Rifle.

The choice of weapons is also pleasing, and their roles in combat are well-shown. As in, machine guns are deadly to both you and your foe, and sniping with any old weapon simply won't work. Grenades also show their role both as a surpression weapon and a room-clearing device.

One of the better brand-name first-person shooters that has a surprisingly high amount of realism, definately look into this one.

reviewText:
It's a good game with some unique gameplay while parachuting into open levels and choosing where to start the missions. There's also an interesting AI system used with the enemies called Affordance AI. Which causes them to move around and take cover in a fun and engaging way.

Most of the guns feel great especialy the sniper rifles with some cool lensing effects on the scopes. There's not much of a story but there's a couple of shocking moments that make up for this especialy towards the end. I also liked the way the missions are introduced and I think the developers made some good design choices to encourage immersion.

I played casualy through all the missions in about 9 hours and unlocked around a third of the extra content and weapon upgrades. The last two levels are particularly good and where the game really comes into it's own.

There's some replay value here too with all the unlockable stuff. There's also a multiplayer mode which I didn't try. However I read online that a group called War Lions has kept this mode alive.

The game runs in 1080p at a solid 60FPS for me, on a GTX 980 with Windows 10. I read that some people have needed to install legacy Physx drivers to get it to work, I didnt have this problem.

The graphics still look pretty good and can be ehanched to look even better with SweetFx. The game is unfortunately fairly blurry though when moving around. However motion blur can be disabled by editing the .ini files which helps this a lot. The FOV can also be increased in the same way.

So with a few tweaks the game runs pretty good for me, certainly enough to enjoy the experience. It can still be a bit blurry but it's definitely worth playing regardless. At the time it was released in late 2007, the developers seemed to be genuinely trying something different and for the most part it works. It reminds me of Wolfenstein (2009) I even got a bit of a supernatural vibe off one of the Nazi enemies during the later missions. I had a lot of fun with this one and I highly recommend it.

However, I think Airborne beats Call of Duty 2 as far as the gameplay, controls, and story go. reviewText:
This game can be infuriating. But it can also be a lot of fun.
It took me 12 hours to beat the game and then go back and get all the weapon upgrades for every weapon and the grenades.

AI Issues
The enemy AI is extremely dumb and very spastic, they will hunker down against an object and keep repositioning themselves so they become impossible to shoot sometimes and they can straight up teleport because of the AI's cover system. They move around so much even when un-alerted, they give us sufferers of ADHD a bad name. They can shoot you through walls and the tiniest cracks in them and other objects. They never miss a grenade throw and some single enemies can chuck EIGHT grenades at you in a split second. They've thrown grenades through tiny cracks in the walls that are impossible for the grenades to fit through and yet they still manage to go through.
Your teammates are just useless cannon fodder but amusingly they'll sometimes band together and run at the enemies and all of them melee a single enemy at once running this devilishy satisfying fist train on them and insta kill the enemy sending their body FLYING. The enemies do this too, even to you, they'll come around a corner while you're reloading and ONLY ever do it while you're reloading and run the train on you and instantly kill you. Your teammates WILL ALWAYS get in your way and probably get you killed, they can softly push you around and block your ironsight peeking and they'll do it all the time. They'll run through you and in front of you and sometimes they follow where you're aiming and do nothing but follow your crosshair to be shot, like no joke, seriously. The enemy AI are also aim-botting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. No matter what weapon they're using, they'll shoot you from a far distance and get a headshot and take %50 of your health. And other times, they're super dumb and miss every shot, but most of the  time they land every shot even if they're gun is aiming at the ground and they're running the other way. Their bullets can apparently eject out of their barrel at a sharp 90 degree angle and they can blindfire around any object and ALWAYS hit you. It's never missed me once, even when I'm behind cover. And a common problem, you'll enter a new area before there's any cover and you'll be shot by every enemy there at the same time instantly killing you. Your teammates will almost always cause the RPG enemies to hit you, they'll run across the battlefield and the RPG enemy fires at them and it completely misses them and hits you even if you're behind cover even when the RPG enemy has no clue where you are, thanks to your useless cannon fodder buddies. I died more times because of this than any other means of death in this game. It happens with the tanks too. I've walked through a door my buddy ran through only to be hit in the face by a tank shell and insta-killed.
Enemies also have infinite clips and randomly reload even if they don't need to and RPG guys? They can fire as many rockets as they want without reloading and then all of a sudden they decide to reload the rocket launcher only to fire it at you again before they've even dropped the rocket in the launcher, and they can be facing the other way and then just turn around and fire instantly exactly where you're standing, all enemies do this though so it's to be expected, even snipers that can one shot kill you like this as well. And mind you, this entire time, I'm playing on NORMAL, not HARD. I tried hard and it's almost exactly the same, but their weapons do more damage, that's the only difference, you can be shot twice by an MP40 and die but it can take a whole clip from a Thompson to down a single enemy. And even in normal mode, most enemies can take more bullets to their face than you can but a grenade at 20ft away or rocket of the same distance is insta death to them but not you if you have full health.
Your buddies will also almost always fail their grenade throws and it bounces back right on top of you which can damage you. Your grenades also kill your buddies, so if you throw one, your buddy will 99% of the time try to play fetch with you and be blown clear across the sky where he is truly part of the Airborne now.

Bugs
This game has no option to adjust FOV and I had to adjust it using the fixes provided on PCGWiki. It's a normal problem with UE3 games and you need to adjust the FOV every time you start a new level, with the fix you just hit Page Down to make the FOV accurate. Also, get rid of the sprint effects if you don't want to get motion sickness.

reviewText:
Not your traditional MoH, but still a great game nonetheless. What sets Airborne apart from previous MoH games is that you are not a single agent sneaking behind enemy lines; instead, you are a paratrooper dropping into a large scale battle. The “one man army” feeling is nonetheless preserved, for better or worse. Fellow NPC paratroopers accompany you throughout each mission, though their combat effectiveness is questionable. They neither help nor hinder you very much in gameplay, though they at least provide cinematic backdrop for sense of a larger scale ground battle.

Perhaps the biggest difference between Airborne and past MoH games is its nonlinearity. At the beginning of each level you (as the title might suggest) jump out of an airplane and land on the battlefield. During this jump you can steer your character towards anywhere you want to land (to an extent). Upon landing you are tasked with completing a number of objectives which are spread throughout the map. You may carry out these objectives in any order you please before a new area is unlocked through which you will complete the finale to the mission. This is a far cry to previous games of the series and in some ways it is therefore lacking. There are much less cinematic moments in Airborne that the series has been known for (like running across a family having dinner in Frontline), and entire missions take place in relatively the same battleground. In this vein, the game is somewhat disappointing. However, this it makes up in replayability. The singleplayer campaign clocks in around 5 hours long on normal (which is a bit short), however the freedom to start missions (almost) wherever you want and complete objectives in any order you want allows for exta hours of gameplay in comparison to MoH’s generally more scripted level design. In addition, there are various unlockables and collectibles such as weapon upgrades (unlocked by killing enemies) and “skill drops” (marked places on the map where you can land).

If collectibles aren’t something you’re particularly into, the gameplay itself is a blast. Each weapon is punchy and satisfying to use. At the start of a each mission you can choose your own loadout, allowing for multiple playstyles. Want to land on a rooftop and pick off your enemies with a sniper rifle? You can do that. Want to run and gun through the streets with a thompson? You can do that too. To that end, the game allows you to choose your own pace. You can race through the mission if you please, completing objectives as quickly as possible, or you can simply take your time, picking off enemies one by one. In gameplay, Airborne truly does feel a lot like a MoH game, yet more open to different playstyles. One unique feature in Airborne is a Ravenshield-esque leaning system. Whilst aiming down the sights you can press the WASD keys to lean your character to and fro in different directions. Unfortunately, whilst doing this, you cannot move from where you are standing (unless you hold shift as I later found out). It is by no means a bad feature, but its implementation is strange and makes movement in the game awkward sometimes. The game would certainly benefit from the ability to toggle this feature but alas, there is none.

Airborne offers a new experience for MoH veterans, perhaps not one they may have hoped for, but a fun one nonetheless. Hardcore fans may have trouble accepting Airborne as a true MoH game, and maybe it isn’t, but it is by no means worth passing up.

reviewText:
A very interesting mechanic poorly executed.

Being able to jump out of a plane to land anywhere on the field is a neat idea. You can land on a roof and shoot your way down, or land behind the enemy and flank them.

And that’s about where the good ends.

The weapons have a neat level-up mechanic. The more you use a certain weapon, you will earn attachments for it, and make it better. Unfortunately, at the beginning of the game when you don’t have any proficiencies, the weapons are incredibly difficult to use. I remember having a rifle, looking down the sights at an enemy’s chest, and emptying entire magazines without a single hit. The inaccuracy of the weapons in this game can make it very frustrating.

The enemies scale, and get more difficult as you progress. That’s good. The highest level enemies, though, are laughable and unrealistic. Also, after five legitimate missions, the sixth and final mission feels like a giant spoof of the entire game.

Lastly, the game’s big gimmick is parachuting to any place on the battlefield. I never once learned how to land correctly. The instructions were not very clear, and after failing all three times in the tutorial, I was approved and sent off to war. I played every mission, and made countless landings, and botched every single one. I was upset that I couldn’t do it, but even more upset that I couldn’t LEARN to do it.

This game was a novelty when I was looking for something I hadn’t played before, but it’s not something I’ll ever go back to with fond memories.

I'm not a big fan of the FPS genre so I might just be wrong, but from what I've seen in this game, MOH:A isn't a very good game. There isn't much to the game in terms of story, and usually you'd expect more from the gameplay. But then the very clunky control scheme is what pretty much ruins the experience. You can't move at all while aiming, which can get really annoying and disadvantageous. Simply switching to a lower difficulty still doesn't cut it.

Another sort of nitpick I have with this game is that when you shoot at an enemy, there is very little if at all any realistic signs on the target if it's been hit. It could be anything, be it a moan, blood splatter or at least falling back a bit due to the impact of the bullet, or whatever. But here you only know you've hit an enemy when they die, apparently. This just makes no sense because ... seriously no human can endure getting shot without a wince and still keep shooting until they're down. That's just ridiculous.

Not a very good FPS overall to me personally. I don't know much about this genre, but certainly there are things that the Call of Duty series has been doing way better than this game even since its first installment.

reviewText:
I am a pretty big fan of the good ol' Medal of Honor series, but as much as it hurts to say this, I can't really recommend this one. Yeah, I've played for mere minutes, but there's a reason for that. First off, upon my first start up of the game, I was waiting ever so patiently for it to install all the useless stuff, only for it to tell me that my graphics card is not supported. Now, because I have an Intel HD 4200, I can understand why this wouldn't work. Obviously, I wasn't gonna call it a day there. I looked around, searched the forums, the Googles, and found something called PhysX Legacy. Several places said installing this would make it work. Did that, no difference.

I then found someone saying to just rename the setup .exe in the games files, and upon doing that, the game actually started up.

And now, to the actual game itself.

Because the setup was renamed, the game kinda ignored all the graphical stuff, and does not allow me to mess with the graphics settings. When playing a cutscene, most, if not all the characters are simply black silhouettes. I was watching as one of them was showing me my objective in a town in Italy, which just turned out to be a blank wall. So, if you end up like I did where your card is not suppoted, you can't do much about the cutscenes.

Now, the gameplay. The first mission, and probably every single other mission, starts out with you jumping out of a plane. You parachute into the town, your objective to take out AA and artillery guns. Now, this is just my opinion, but I didn't like the fact that it didn't matter what order I completed my objectives. I found myself running through the empty streets, from one side of the town to the other, all of a sudden running into some firefight close to the objective. I've played Allied Assault, European Assault, Rising Sun, Vanguard, and the missions were all linear and not really picky. I think that's how it should have been with Airborne. The idea of choosing how to do the mission is cool, but something about the topic and the way it was executed just makes me think that it's not as good as it could be. In Vanguard, you did the same thing, jump, land, and one by one finish your job. In Airborne, you jump, and you can finish the mission as you please.

The shooting is a bit odd to me, but that's probably because I'm used to shooting without iron sights, like in the old MoHs. You can sprint, the health bar is different than just about every other MoH, giving you 4 bars that can regenerate with either health packs or just over time, so long as the bar is not empty. In Vanguard, it worked like CoD, get shot, wait a few, its like nothing happened. In the older ones, you had 100 health, and could only get more if you picked up bottles, medkits, etc.

I do not reccomend because the game is simply too much of a pain in the ♥♥♥ to get up and running, and if you have the problem I had, you will not be able to toy around with the graphic settings. Hell, there isn't even an option to do so, other than brightness and whatnot. The multiplayer is also a major disappointment, as there is only 10 or less people playing. Allied Assault has more players than this game, and that's a game from 2002. If you're concerned about the story of it, it's World War 2. Not your forte? Go back to your futuristic bolonga. Medal of Honor Airborne was probably amazing in its day, but in 2014, it only causes problems and disappointment.

reviewText: As a veteran of many shooters in last 15 years, I feel pretty comfortable writing this review. I also feel cheated and betrayed, both by developers and people who wrote positive reviews about this... monstrosity. I'll try to be brief - combat doesn't work. No amount of sensitivity tweaking has helped the feeling as if I was playing with gamepad, only I was still holding my mouse. That's how inprecise and awkward aiming and movement in general feels. There is also leaning system, and it's useless. It's not that the leaning system is a terrible idea, but it's executed horribly. Wolfenstein: New World Order actually uses that feature well, but here, it's just infuriating. There is nothing in this game that would keep anyone who was some sense of decency to come back. I will recommend almost any other FPS over this, just play the previous Medal of Honor, hell, original Call of Duty, even though it hasn't aged well, is still a good, satisfying game - get that over this and enjoy your time. Airborne was first truly miserable Medal of honor game and the less people remember it, the better.

If you have never played a Medal of Honor game before, you will probably be saying to yourself COD does this so much better" as you play.  And it is largely true.  But those of you who have played Medal of Honor since the series started will find some nostalgic fun factor here.

reviewText:
Medal of Honor: Airborne is one of those slightly older, but still amazing WW2-era shooter games. I played lots of modern shooters recently too, and everything's simply too linear, with no room for improvisation.

What I loved about this game is that you get a set of objectives to complete on a map (Single player), but it's absolutely up to you how you complete them or in what order. I also like the idea that you still have a health bar, which, believe it or not, is a lot more realistic to me than being able to get shot an unlimited number of times...

It definitely has a MoH:Allied Assault feel to it, which is great because that was an amazing game in its own right. I also loved the fact that they revived some of the old music from MoHAA as well.

Overall: Buy it if you love slightly older WW2 shooters from the CoD 1/2 or MoHAA generation, you won't regret it!

reviewText:
Medal of Honor: Airborne is a tragic gem. Simultaneously the culmination of EA’s original Medal of Honor franchise, and the moment when gamers had enough of the wretchedly overdone setting. We were sick of it all: The European landscape, the same inadequate weapons, the bombastic orchestrated music that blared as you shot the same enemy types over and over (and the enemy types were: the guy who shot at you with a machine gun, and the guy who shot at you with a rifle.)

There use to be a time when that got us excited. When we were fresh off of Saving Private Ryan and Band of Brothers and being able to witness something like Omaha Beach was a incredible, petrifying experience, even if the rest of the game was your standard first person shooter. But as we were most exposed, it quickly became white noise to us, as Medal of Honor’s developer 2015 studios split up to become “Infinity Ward” and make it’s competing brand “Call of Duty”. The genre was looking somewhat crowded before (with Wolfenstein, and Battlefield becoming popular franchises), but then every year we were bombarded by more and more World War 2 titles. From 2004 to 2007, we had six Medal of Honor games and eight Call of Duties. Not to mention other properties joining the fray with Band of Brothers, Red Orchestra, Day of Defeat, World War 2 Combat, World War II: Online, Combat Elite, Sniper Elite, etc. I’m getting a little nauseous just thinking about it.

So it’s 2007, the idea of a World War 2 game has been explored, interpreted, and beaten into the ground so much that a screenshot of a new game with the setting sends viewers into a narcoleptic deep sleep (or in World at War’s case, unbridled rage.) EA looks upon it’s bruised, wheezing Medal of Honor license and a single tear rolls down John Riccitiello’s face as he remembers the glory days of the series. What began as a Goldeneye clone became a front runner to one of the most popular and celebrated sub-genres in our history of gaming. But in 2007 it was a dying giant, it’s extinction inevitable as Call of Duty: Modern Warfare approaches it, and EA Los Angeles knows. With one last gasp of air, Medal of Honor: Airborne was created. The giant dies, the fad is dead, and nobody cared.

But now it’s 2012, we’re no longer constantly exposed to European beaches, Panzer tanks, and young Americans yelling at you to go somewhere. Nobody dares to make another WW2 game, as they’re a profit black hole these days. Modern war has replaced it, but for now we have an opportunity. The white noise that we chose to ignore is now gone, and I can, and am able, to go return to World War 2 without fatigue.

Medal of Honor: Airborne is a weird thing to go back to. After playing so many modern first person shooters, after playing so many games that featured steroid induced bad boys with the personality of tweens, fighting faceless enemies in some truly disgusting ways that we’ve now become immune too. MoHA was suppose to breath new life into what was a somewhat dying franchise. Instead it killed it so hard that it needed a reboot that also didn't live up to expectation. It only takes a few hours of playing to see the faults.

First off, the concept is not bad on paper. At the start of each mission, you get to jump out of a plane, and land where you want. It also gets real ♥♥♥♥ing annoying that you have to do this over and over each time you die.

The next problem is the lean/cover system. The idea is again, good on paper. Whilst aiming down sights, you can lean or go prone using the movement keys, or move slowly by holding the sprint key. The problem is that this doesn't work under stress. I'm use to being able to move whilst in iron sights, and I am use to using other buttons for lean. There is a reason this has not been used again.

EA obviously saw Crysis and thought it would be a good idea and put it into a WWII game, therefore it has a 'non-linear' level form. This doesn't ♥♥♥♥ing fit with the theme. These are well-planned military operations. People go certain places and do certain jobs in a certain order. You don't just run around willy-nilly doing whatever objective seems like it would be the funnest.

AI is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. Allies constantly rush towards Nazis and die quickly. They also have a habit of getting in the way of you when you are trying to ♥♥♥♥ing shoot someone. The enemies themselves constantly leave cover.

The difficulty comes from a few parts of this game. First of all, health drops are barely around. THIS IS A HUGE ♥♥♥♥ING PROBLEM. It really ♥♥♥♥ing sucks dying after playing for 10 minutes, because there are no ♥♥♥♥ing health kits available. It's not hard to add a few health kits. It's simple level design.

You also can die really quickly. MG 42s tear you apart before you can blink. Enemies can bum rush you and melee you to death. I've had enemies do this to me, whilst surviving automatic gunfire. It's complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Apart from that, damage does seem fairly balanced. Now I understand an MG 42 would tear you apart in real life, but this isn't ARMA, and it's sure as hell annoying having to go back to a checkpoint when you are just rapidly killed by an MG 42 nest that you either couldn't kill in time, or didn't see.

The weapon-upgrade system is pretty meh. I don't understand some of the upgrades. For example, the shotgun gets a bayonet, but why not instead the M1 Garand? It makes more sense as the shotgun is designed for close quarters. IT'S A SHOTGUN FOR ♥♥♥♥S SAKE! The M1 however is better at long range, and it would make sense that if an enemy catches you off guard that you may have to stick them.

Story is non-existent. There is no reason to care about your fellow soldiers. They're just cannon fodder. Just go mission to mission shooting that and blowing up this. I honestly couldn't care less by the second mission.

Here's an idea, how about make it you're the squad leader, and during mission planning, you choose where to drop. Maybe one drop gets you closer to the enemy, but is very risky, or one takes you to close to good high ground where you can pick off some Germans. This would give merit to the whole 'jumping out of a plane' gimmick, and allowed for a more interesting game.

Having played Allied Assault, I can easily say its a much better game, despite being much older. Brothers in Arms: Hell's Highway was also based around paratroopers, but did everything much better (except you don't get to jump out of a plane).

8/10 Major Fret's would send this game to the gas chamber.

reviewText:
Very solid FPS set in WWII.

The campaign consists of 6 long missions and offers 3 difficulty levels. I've played on the highest (Expert) and each mission took me ~ 90-120 minutes (with the exception of the last one which required a LOT of tries) due to slower approach.

I haven't played multi-player yet (and probably never will) so I can't review that part of the game.

Things I liked:
- Non-linear approach which allows me to land almost anywhere and choose the way I want to beat the given part - this is definitely a unique selling point of the game.
- Wide selection of weapons and their upgrades. Each weapon has 3 upgrade which gradually unlock after given number of kills.
- Enemy A.I. which utilizes cover and even though the enemies don't respawn, they're able to create a very tight defense which can provide very long gunfights.
- Cover system which makes the Expert difficulty challenging, but still fair.
- Springfield rifle; the best in-game weapon, hands down.

Things I disliked:
- Unbalanced difficulty in case of otherwise fantastic last level. Groups of MG-42 wielding elite soldiers which can take you down in a second, combined with sparse checkpoints can be quite frustrating.
- Severe lack of physics. Soldiers are the only in-game entities which are affected by a physics system, which is quite flawed. Some soldiers get thrown back by 5 meters when hit by a bullet. Some others fly 20 meters up when hit by a grenade. Fortunately, these hilarious events are not that common.
- Weird hitboxes. Some soldiers can survive 2 headshots while others die immediately when hit in their foot.
- Censorship. I hate Nazis as much as the next guy, but replacing the swastika by a different symbol (regular symmetric cross) is not the right solution, especially in case of a game which takes place during an important part of history. The same with almost no blood - it makes a war game more fun to play which doesn't feel.... right.

Nonetheless, I enjoyed the game and will probably play it again some time in the future - and I'd recommend you to do the same.

reviewText:
Very solid FPS set in WWII.

The campaign consists of 6 long missions and offers 3 difficulty levels. I've played on the highest (Expert) and each mission took me ~ 90-120 minutes (with the exception of the last one which required a LOT of tries) due to slower approach.

I haven't played multi-player yet (and probably never will) so I can't review that part of the game.

Things I liked:
- Non-linear approach which allows me to land almost anywhere and choose the way I want to beat the given part - this is definitely a unique selling point of the game.
- Wide selection of weapons and their upgrades. Each weapon has 3 upgrade which gradually unlock after given number of kills.
- Enemy A.I. which utilizes cover and even though the enemies don't respawn, they're able to create a very tight defense which can provide very long gunfights.
- Cover system which makes the Expert difficulty challenging, but still fair.
- Springfield rifle; the best in-game weapon, hands down.

Things I disliked:
- Unbalanced difficulty in case of otherwise fantastic last level. Groups of MG-42 wielding elite soldiers which can take you down in a second, combined with sparse checkpoints can be quite frustrating.
- Severe lack of physics. Soldiers are the only in-game entities which are affected by a physics system, which is quite flawed. Some soldiers get thrown back by 5 meters when hit by a bullet. Some others fly 20 meters up when hit by a grenade. Fortunately, these hilarious events are not that common.
- Weird hitboxes. Some soldiers can survive 2 headshots while others die immediately when hit in their foot.
- Censorship. I hate Nazis as much as the next guy, but replacing the swastika by a different symbol (regular symmetric cross) is not the right solution, especially in case of a game which takes place during an important part of history. The same with almost no blood - it makes a war game more fun to play which doesn't feel.... right.

Nonetheless, I enjoyed the game and will probably play it again some time in the future - and I'd recommend you to do the same.

Having rented this game back on the xbox around the time it came out, I had fond memories of a slightly above average WW2 shooter with some great levels. Unfortunately, it seems that nostalgia clouded my recollection of this game.  While not terrible, it is certainly no more than an average WW2 shooter.  Question is, is it worth $10?

If you have an itch to replay the highly oversaturated WW2 genre of the 2000's, then I would say this game is worth the ten bucks.  If you are just looking for a fun shooter, save your money for one of the million better FPS games out there.

The hook for this game that attempts to seperate it from other WW2 shooters is that you are a paratrooper.  This is reflected in the the level design through the gameplay mechanic of you begining  the levels by jumping out of a plane and steering where you want to start.  It's an intresting (if a bit shallow) gameplay mechanic that lends to some fun replay value for a few levels.  For example, do you land on streets with your allies, or behind enemy lines in the thick of things? Landing on roofs, towers, and german soldiers before ambushing them is probably the best part of this game.

As for the shooting itself, its pretty sub par.  Often the bullets will miss their targets for no reason, even when aiming directly at enemies. I understand that the sub machines guns should have a shorter range then rifles, but its just way too short to be taken seriously.  While long range shooting can be more effective, it takes way too long to pick off enemies from a distance, leading to tedious games of whack a mole while germans run around taking multiple shots to the head.  Close range combat is much more fun, but due to the sloopy shooting mechanics its quite dangerous.  In later levels, where the enemies become quite tough, its just not an option you can rely on, and you'll be back to tedious cover shooting.  Another thing to note concerning the shooting and weaponry is that allied weapons become pretty obsolete in the long run.  Since you are  a paratrooper and are dropping into enemy territory, there are not many american weapons laying around. reviewText:
MOH has always been an outstanding series in the FPS genre.  Until, of course, their recent and final release known as Warfighter.  Airborne puts you in a position of the 82nd Airborne division.  Just like Vanguard, you push up through Sicily and into France to clear the way for Operation Overlord; also known as D-Day.

For a game that released almost seven years ago, its still amazing.  Yeah the controls are a little wacky, especially with the ADS when it comes to completely stopping.  After getting use to the controls, its fun and easy.

What I always liked about the MOH series, is that as you progress through the campaign, the missions get harder no matter the difficulty.  The campaign is a good 5-6 hours depending on how much time you take.  Every time you die, the game respawns you back in the plane.  Now, that does sound bad, but it isn't actually, since you get to parachute back down to whatever objectives that was not finished.  I think it was the right step to take when developing this game.

Due to its 32-bit limitations (if pc is 64-bit) it will break in the setup menu.  Just accept everything and start it from there.  The game would keep crashing if you do not proceed.

Everything else that's in the game, I would rather for you to figure it out and expierence yourself.  Ima give this game an 8.9/10 just due to the 32-bit limitations.

reviewText:
There is a lot great about this game - I honestly do love it... but if a game doesn't have great mouse controls, it isn't very fun to play. Very simple.

It was a great game for its time, but I really do just hate the accuracy of the guns. For example, even if you shoot straight at an enemy's head, with your ironsights, you may or may not get a headshot. I don't know why it does that, but it is really annoying and ruins the experience. It's fine if there is a lot of recoil to the guns or the bullets have a certain effect that you have to adjust to, but no, with this game, even if you think you are dead on, you will miss half your shots by some random calculation, especially if you are trying to go for headshot medals.

The other problem wrong with the mouse controls is that the ironsights sensitivity is much quicker than the hipfire sensitivity on all the guns. Normally it would be the other way around, where ironsights would slow down to help with your accuracy, but no, with this game everything is backwards in regards to mouse controls.

Anyway, I will recommend this game as most people who pick this up will probably not have good mouse control awareness and therefore will probably enjoy the difficulty of picking off the enemies, and of course, all the history about the Airborne.

Overall, this has to be one of the most enjoyable WW2 shooters I've played, despite it's obvious flaws.
